questions.text: Your company has a 3 tier architecture setup for some of its applications with an internet facing web tier, a business logic tier, and a data store tier. In this setup...
answers: …the web and business logic tiers would go in a public subnet and the data store tier would go in a private subnet
…the web tier would go in a public subnet and the data store and business logic tiers would go in a private subnet
All three would go in a public subnet since this is a web application
All three would go in a private subnet to keep the app secure
correctAnswers: …the web tier would go in a public subnet and the data store and business logic tiers would go in a private subnet

Your company has a separate AWS accounts for its IT department, Applications department, and its Data Science department. There is VPC peering setup between the Applications Department and the IT department, and there is another peering connection between the IT department and the Data Science Department. The Applications team needs to collaborate on a project with the Data Science team and would like to use internal network to communicate between services. What do they need to do in order to set this up?
answers: Nothing, both accounts should be able to communicate with each other via their peering connections to the IT account
Set up a VPC peering connection between the Data Science department account and the Applications department account
Enable transitive peering in the IT account
correctAnswers: Set up a VPC peering connection between the Data Science department account and the Applications department account

questions.text: Can you have overlapping IP addresses in accounts that have VPC peering enabled between them?
answers: Yes, but you need to specify which accounts via the console or API

You set up a NAT instance, but you are still unable to reach the internet via EC2 instances running in your private subnet. Which of the following could be causing the failure in your setup?
answers: Your NAT instance is in a public subnet
You need to disable the Source Destination Check on the NAT instance
Your NAT instance is not in the same AZ as your EC2 instance
correctAnswers: You need to disable the Source Destination Check on the NAT instance
